s.text: This year, the Secret Service costs taxpayers about $590 million and employs more than 4,600 people--including 2,000 special agents (whose responsibilities include presidential protection) and 1,200 officers in the Uniformed Division.

This year, the Secret Service costs taxpayers about $590 million and employs more than 4,600 people--including 2,000 special agents (whose responsibilities include presidential protection) and 1,200 officers in the Uniformed Division.
A half-century ago, a president could drive through city streets in a normal car with a few bodyguards, and anyone could stroll up to the front door of the White House.
It's that no one knows whether they are necessary and no one is willing to ask.
It's that no one knows whether they are necessary and no one is willing to ask.
But should it be forbidden to ask if we could spend less and do less to protect him?
